docs.lead_paragraph: The muscular young man on the narrow cot winced visibly as an acupuncturist, Hansen Mok, removed and reattached the hair-thin needle with the electrodes attached to it. The procedure really did not hurt, he said; it was just a reflex to the needle. ''It's more a psychological thing.'' The needles properly placed, Mr. Mok adjusted the rate of the electrical impulses flowing into the needles, and, for 30 minutes, the young man, undergoing a novel method of drug detoxification at the Haight-Ashbury Free Medical Clinic, relaxed and let the mild current do its work.

headline.main: ACUPUNCTURE USED TO TREAT DRUG ABUSE

docs.snippet: The muscular young man on the narrow cot winced visibly as an acupuncturist, Hansen Mok, removed and reattached the hair-thin needle with the electrodes attached to it.   The procedure really did not hurt, he said; it was just a reflex to the needle....

byline.original: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times
